member.summary: Provides functions for executing command prompt commands.

member.name: M:SilDev.CmdExec.Send(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Diagnostics.ProcessWindowStyle,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class to execute system commands using the system command prompt ("cmd.exe").
This can be useful for an unprivileged application as a simple way to execute a command with the highest user permissions, for example.
member.param: The command to execute.
to start the application with administrator privileges; otherwise, .
The window state to use when the process is started.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The location of the executables.

The command line arguments format string that is used to create archives from directories.
Please note that two formation keys must be defined; {0} is the source directory path and {1} is the destination archive path.
Example:
"a \"{1}\\*\" \"{0}\""

The command line arguments format string that is used to create archives from files.
Please note that two formation keys must be defined; {0} is the source file path and {1} is the destination archive path.
Example:
"a \"{1}\" \"{0}\""

The command line arguments format string that is used to extract archives.
Please note that two formation keys must be defined; {0} is the source archive path and {1} is the destination directory path.
Example:
"x -ad \"{0}\" \"{1}\""

member.summary:
The command line arguments format string that is used to extract archives.

Example:
"x \"{0}\" -o\"{1}\" -y"
Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param:
The name of the application; should be the name of the default installation directory.
Example:
"7-Zip"

The alternate name of the application.
Example:
"7z"
The location of the executables.

A sequence of execution file names that can be used to create archives.
Please note that only the file found first is used. All other defined files are only alternatives.
Example:
new string[] { "7zG.exe", "7z.exe", ... }

A sequence of execution file names that can be used to extract archives. The rules are the same as for the parameter.
Can be if the same files are used to create and extract.

The command line arguments format string that is used to create archives from directories.
Please note that two formation keys must be defined; {0} is the source directory path and {1} is the destination archive path.
Example:
"a -t7z \"{1}\\*\" \"{0}\""

member.name: F:SilDev.Forms.FormBorderlessResizable.WindowsMessage.NcHitTest
member.summary: Sent to a window in order to determine what part of the window corresponds to a particular screen coordinate. This can happen, for example, when the cursor moves, when a mouse button is pressed or released, or in response to a call to a function such as WindowFromPoint. If the mouse is not captured, the message is sent to the window beneath the cursor. Otherwise, the message is sent to the window that has captured the mouse.

member.name: T:SilDev.Forms.MessageBoxEx
member.summary:
Displays a message window, also known as a dialog box, based on , which presents a message to the user. It is a modal window, blocking other actions in the application until the user closes it. A can contain text, buttons, and symbols that inform and instruct the user.
The difference to is that the message window displays in the center of the specified owner object.

member.name: T:SilDev.Ini.IniDirect
member.summary: Provides static functions for accessing INI files using the Win32 API.

member.name: M:SilDev.Ini.IniDirect.Read(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Retrieves the value from the specified section of an INI file.
The Win32-API without file caching is used for reading in this case. Please note that empty sections are not permitted.
member.param: The file path of the INI file to read.
The name of the section containing the key name.
The name of the key whose associated value is to be retrieved.

member.name: M:SilDev.Ini.IniDirect.Write(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Copies the representation of the specified value into the specified section of an INI file. If the file does not exist, it is created.
The Win32-API is used for writing in this case. Please note that empty sections are not permitted and that this function writes all changes directly on the disk, which means that the entire file is rewritten every time. This causes many write accesses when used incorrectly.
member.param: The path of the INI file to write.
The name of the section to which the value will be copied.

The name of the key to be associated with a value.
If this parameter is , the entire section, including all entries within the section, is deleted.

The value to be written to the file.
If this parameter is , the key pointed to by the key parameter is deleted.
to enable overwriting of a key with the same value as specified; otherwise, .
to skip an existing value, even it is not the same value as specified; otherwise, .

member.name: T:SilDev.ProcessPrincipal
member.summary: Provides the functionality to handle the current principal name.

member.name: P:SilDev.ProcessPrincipal.Name
member.summary:
Gets the original name of the current principal.
This variable is only set if was previously called.

member.name: M:SilDev.ProcessPrincipal.GetOriginalName
member.summary: Retrieves the original name of the current principal.

member.name: M:SilDev.ProcessPrincipal.ChangeName(System.String)
member.summary: Changes the name of the current principal.
member.param: The new name for the current principal, which cannot be longer than the original one.

member.name: M:SilDev.ProcessPrincipal.RestoreName
member.summary: Restores the name of the current principal.

member.name: T:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem
member.summary: Provides quick access to WMI class properties.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.BootDevice
member.summary:
Gets the name of the disk drive from which the Windows operating system starts.
Example: "\\Device\Harddisk0"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.BuildNumber
member.summary:
Gets the build number of an operating system. It can be used for more precise version information than product release version numbers.
Example: "1381".

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.BuildType
member.summary:
Gets the type of build used for an operating system.
Examples: "retail build", "checked build"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Caption
member.summary:
Gets the operating system version.
Example: "Microsoft Windows 7 Enterprise"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CodeSet
member.summary: Gets the code page value an operating system uses. A code page contains a character table that an operating system uses to translate strings for different languages. The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) lists values that represent defined code pages. If an operating system does not use an ANSI code page, this member is set to 0 (zero). The CodeSet string can use a maximum of six characters to define the code page value.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CountryCode
member.summary:
Gets the code for the country/region that an operating system uses. Values are based on international phone dialing prefixes-also referred to as IBM country/region codes. This property can use a maximum of six characters to define the country/region code value.
Example: "1" (United States)

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CreationClassName
member.summary: Gets the name of the first concrete class that appears in the inheritance chain used in the creation of an instance. When used with other key properties of the class, this property allows all instances of this class and its subclasses to be identified uniquely.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CSCreationClassName
member.summary: Gets the creation class name of the scoping computer system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CSDVersion
member.summary: Gets a -terminated string that indicates the latest service pack installed on a computer. If no service pack is installed, the string is .

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CSName
member.summary: Gets the name of the scoping computer system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.CurrentTimeZone
member.summary: Gets the number, in minutes, an operating system is offset from Greenwich mean time (GMT). The number is positive, negative, or zero.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.DataExecutionPrevention_32BitApplications
member.summary: Gets the Data Execution Prevention. When the Data Execution Prevention hardware feature is available, this property indicates that the feature is set to work for 32-bit applications if . On 64-bit computers, the Data Execution Prevention feature is configured in the Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store and the properties in are set accordingly.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.DataExecutionPrevention_Available
member.summary: Gets the Data Execution Prevention that is a hardware feature to prevent buffer overrun attacks by stopping the execution of code on data-type memory pages. If , then this feature is available. On 64-bit computers, the Data Execution Prevention feature is configured in the BCD store and the properties in are set accordingly.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.DataExecutionPrevention_Drivers
member.summary: Gets the Data Execution Prevention. When the Data Execution Prevention hardware feature is available, this property indicates that the feature is set to work for drivers if . On 64-bit computers, the Data Execution Prevention feature is configured in the BCD store and the properties in are set accordingly.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.DataExecutionPrevention_SupportPolicy
member.summary:
Gets the value indicating which Data Execution Prevention (DEP) setting is applied. The DEP setting specifies the extent to which DEP applies to 32-bit applications on the system. DEP is always applied to the Windows kernel.
Always Off (0): DEP is turned off for all 32-bit applications on the computer with no exceptions. This setting is not available for the user interface.
Always On (1): DEP is enabled for all 32-bit applications on the computer. This setting is not available for the user interface.
Opt In (2): DEP is enabled for a limited number of binaries, the kernel, and all Windows-based services. However, it is off by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator must explicitly choose either the Always On or the Opt Out setting before DEP can be applied to 32-bit applications.
Opt Out (3): DEP is enabled by default for all 32-bit applications. A user or administrator can explicitly remove support for a 32-bit application by adding the application to an exceptions list.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Debug
member.summary: Gets the value indicating that the operating system is a checked (debug) build. If , the debugging version is installed. Checked builds provide error checking, argument verification, and system debugging code. Additional code in a checked binary generates a kernel debugger error message and breaks into the debugger. This helps immediately determine the cause and location of the error. Performance may be affected in a checked build due to the additional code that is executed.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Description
member.summary: Gets the description of the Windows operating system. Some user interfaces for example, those that allow editing of this description, limit its length to 48 characters.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Distributed
member.summary: Gets the value that specifies if the operating system is distributed across several computer system nodes. If so, these nodes should be grouped as a cluster.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.EncryptionLevel
member.summary: Gets the encryption level for secure transactions: 40-bit, 128-bit, or n-bit.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.ForegroundApplicationBoost
member.summary: Gets the value that increases in priority is given to the foreground application. Application boost is implemented by giving an application more execution time slices (quantum lengths).

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.FreePhysicalMemory
member.summary: Gets the number, in kilobytes, of physical memory currently unused and available.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.FreeSpaceInPagingFiles
member.summary: Gets the number, in kilobytes, that can be mapped into the operating system paging files without causing any other pages to be swapped out.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.FreeVirtualMemory
member.summary: Gets the number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.InstallDate
member.summary: Gets the install date of the operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.LargeSystemCache
member.summary:
Gets the operating system cache optimize option.
0: Optimize memory for applications.
1: Optimize memory for system performance.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.LastBootUpTime
member.summary: Gets the date and time the operating system was last restarted.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.LocalDateTime
member.summary: Gets the operating system version of the local date and time-of-day.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Locale
member.summary: Gets the language identifier used by the operating system. A language identifier is a standard international numeric abbreviation for a country/region. Each language has a unique language identifier (LANGID), a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Manufacturer
member.summary: Gets the name of the operating system manufacturer. For Windows-based systems, this value is "Microsoft Corporation".

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.MaxNumberOfProcesses
member.summary: Gets the maximum number of process contexts the operating system can support. The default value set by the provider is 4294967295 (0xFFFFFFFF). If there is no fixed maximum, the value should be 0 (zero). On systems that have a fixed maximum, this object can help diagnose failures that occur when the maximum is reached-if unknown, enter 4294967295 (0xFFFFFFFF).

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.MaxProcessMemorySize
member.summary: Gets the maximum number, in kilobytes, of memory that can be allocated to a process. For operating systems with no virtual memory, typically this value is equal to the total amount of physical memory minus the memory used by the BIOS and the operating system. For some operating systems, this value may be infinity, in which case 0 (zero) should be entered. In other cases, this value could be a constant, for example, 2G or 4G.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.MUILanguages
member.summary: Gets the Multilingual User Interface Pack (MUI Pack) languages installed on the computer. For example, "en-us". MUI Pack languages are resource files that can be installed on the English version of the operating system. When an MUI Pack is installed, you can can change the user interface language to one of 33 supported languages.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the operating system instance within a computer system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.NumberOfLicensedUsers
member.summary: Gets the number of user licenses for the operating system. If unlimited, enter 0 (zero). If unknown, enter -1.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.NumberOfProcesses
member.summary: Gets the number of process contexts currently loaded or running on the operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.NumberOfUsers
member.summary: Gets the number of user sessions for which the operating system is storing state information currently.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OperatingSystemSKU
member.summary: Gets the Stock Keeping Unit (SKU) number for the operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Organization
member.summary: Gets the company name for the registered user of the operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OSArchitecture
member.summary: Gets the architecture of the operating system, as opposed to the processor. This property can be localized.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OSLanguage
member.summary: Gets the language version of the operating system installed. The following list lists the possible values. Example: 0x0807 (German, Switzerland).

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OSProductSuite
member.summary: Gets the installed and licensed system product additions to the operating system. For example, the value of 146 (0x92) for OSProductSuite indicates Enterprise, Terminal Services, and Data Center (bits one, four, and seven set). The following list lists possible values.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OSType
member.summary: Gets the type of operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.OtherTypeDescription
member.summary: Gets the additional description for the current operating system version.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.PAEEnabled
member.summary: Gets the value that specifies whether the physical address extensions (PAE) are enabled by the operating system running on Intel processors. PAE allows applications to address more than 4 GB of physical memory. When PAE is enabled, the operating system uses three-level linear address translation rather than two-level. Providing more physical memory to an application reduces the need to swap memory to the page file and increases performance.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.PortableOperatingSystem
member.summary: Gets the value that specifies whether the operating system booted from an external USB device. If , the operating system has detected it is booting on a supported locally connected storage device.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Primary
member.summary: Gets the value that specifies whether this is the primary operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.ProductType
member.summary: Gets additional system information.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.RegisteredUser
member.summary:
Gets the name of the registered user of the operating system.
Example: "Ben Smith"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SerialNumber
member.summary:
Gets the operating system product serial identification number.
Example: "10497-OEM-0031416-71674"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.ServicePackMajorVersion
member.summary: Gets the major version number of the service pack installed on the computer system. If no service pack has been installed, the value is 0 (zero).

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.ServicePackMinorVersion
member.summary: Gets the minor version number of the service pack installed on the computer system. If no service pack has been installed, the value is 0 (zero).

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SizeStoredInPagingFiles
member.summary: Gets the total number of kilobytes that can be stored in the operating system paging files-0 (zero) indicates that there are no paging files. Be aware that this number does not represent the actual physical size of the paging file on disk.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Status
member.summary: Gets the current status of the object. Various operational and nonoperational statuses can be defined. Operational statuses include: "OK", "Degraded", and "Pred Fail" (an element, such as a SMART-enabled hard disk drive may function properly, but predicts a failure in the near future). Nonoperational statuses include: "Error", "Starting", "Stopping", and "Service". The Service status applies to administrative work, such as mirror-resilvering of a disk, reload of a user permissions list, or other administrative work. Not all such work is online, but the managed element is neither "OK" nor in one of the other states.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SuiteMask
member.summary: Gets the bit flags that identify the product suites available on the system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SystemDevice
member.summary: Gets the physical disk partition on which the operating system is installed.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SystemDirectory
member.summary:
Gets the system directory of the operating system.
Example: "C:\WINDOWS\SYSTEM32"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.SystemDrive
member.summary:
Gets the letter of the disk drive on which the operating system resides.
Example: "C:"

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.TotalSwapSpaceSize
member.summary: Gets the total swap space in kilobytes. This value may be NULL (unspecified) if the swap space is not distinguished from page files. However, some operating systems distinguish these concepts. For example, in UNIX, whole processes can be swapped out when the free page list falls and remains below a specified amount.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.TotalVirtualMemorySize
member.summary: Gets the number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory. For example, this may be calculated by adding the amount of total RAM to the amount of paging space, that is, adding the amount of memory in or aggregated by the computer system to the property, .

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.TotalVisibleMemorySize
member.summary: Gets the total amount, in kilobytes, of physical memory available to the operating system. This value does not necessarily indicate the amount of physical memory, but what is reported to the operating system as available to it.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.Version
member.summary: Gets the version number of the operating system.

member.name: P:SilDev.QuickWmi.Win32_OperatingSystem.WindowsDirectory
member.summary:
Gets the Windows directory of the operating system.
Example: "C:\WINDOWS"

member.name: M:SilDev.DirectoryEx.EnumerateDirectories(System.String,System.String,System.IO.SearchOption)
member.summary: Returns an enumerable collection of directory names that match a search pattern in a specified path, and optionally searches subdirectories.
member.param: The relative or absolute path to the directory to search. This string is not case-sensitive.

The search string to match against the names of directories in path. This parameter can contain a combination of valid literal path and wildcard (* and ?) characters, but doesn't support regular expressions.
One of the enumeration values that specifies whether the search operation should include only the current directory or should include all subdirectories.

member.name: M:SilDev.DirectoryEx.GetUniqueName(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a unique name starting with a given prefix, followed by a hash of the specified length.

This text is at the beginning of the name.
Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the prefix.
The length of the hash. Valid values are 4 through 24.

member.name: M:SilDev.FileEx.GetUniqueName(System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a unique name starting with a given prefix, followed by a hash of the specified length and a specified suffix.
member.param:
This text is at the beginning of the name.
Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the prefix.

This text is at the end of the name.
If it does not begin with a dot, it will be added. Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the suffix.
The length of the hash. Valid values are 4 through 24.
member.exception: prefix or suffix contains invalid characters.

member.summary: Posted to the window with the keyboard focus when a non-system key is pressed.

member.summary: Posted to the window with the keyboard focus when a non-system key is released.

member.name: F:SilDev.VirtualKeyState.SysKeyDown
member.summary: Posted to the window with the keyboard focus when the user presses the F10 key (which activates the menu bar) or holds down the ALT key and then presses another key.

member.name: F:SilDev.VirtualKeyState.SysKeyUp
member.summary: Posted to the window with the keyboard focus when the user releases a key that was pressed while the ALT key was held down.

member.name: T:SilDev.Log
member.summary:
Provides functionality for the catching and logging of handled or unhandled 's.
This class is not intended to replace the Visual Studio debugging tools. It was primarily designed for final releases in which debugging is disabled. Exceptions can be caught entirely so that the end user doesn't get confused unnecessarily. All exceptions are logged and can still reliably help developers.

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.CatchUnhandled
member.summary: to enable the catching of unhandled 's; otherwise, .

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.CurrentCulture
member.summary: Gets or sets the culture for the current thread.

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.DebugMode
member.summary: Gets the current value that determines how 's are caught and logged. For more information see .

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.FileDir
member.summary:
Gets or sets the location of the current LOG file.
If the specified path doesn't exists, it is created.
If the specified path is invalid or this process doesn't have the necessary permissions to write to this location, the location is changed to the Windows specified folder for temporary files.

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.FileName
member.summary: Gets the name of the current LOG file.

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.FilePath
member.summary: Gets the full path of the current LOG file.

member.name: P:SilDev.Log.DebugKey
member.summary:
Gets or sets the key that is used to allow logging by command line arguments or a configuration file. For more information see .
Default:
'DebugMode'

member.name: M:SilDev.Log.ActivateLogging(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Specifies the for the handling of exceptions. This variable can also be specified over an command line argument using method.
The following modes are available:
Logging is disabled
Exceptions are still caught.
If is , unhandled exceptions are also discarded. This can be useful for public releases to prevent any kind of exception notifications to the end user. But the consequences are dangerous if used incorrectly because all exceptions are completely suppressed.
Logging is enabled
Exceptions are caught and logged.
(Recommended)
Logging is enabled
Exceptions are caught and logged. A console window is allocated to display logging in real time.
Logging is enabled
All exceptions are thrown.
member.param: The logging mode to be set.

member.name: M:SilDev.Log.AllowLogging(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Allows you to enable logging by command line arguments or a specified configuration file using the specified regular expression pattern. For more information see .
There are several ways to make the regular expression pattern work:
Use of the Key and Value groups, that are used to search for the correct key within the file and sets its value as logging mode.
It's also possible to define the Value group alone, or even to use no groups at all. That will only check the first matching value.
Available regular expression groups:
Key
Represents the key within the configuration file that contains the value. Must be the value of the property.
Value
Represents the value passed to the method. Must be convertible to .
member.param: The path of the text file to look for the value that determines the logging mode.

The regular expression pattern to match in the specified configuration file.
(The standard pattern has the INI file format, which searches for the appropriate key in all sections and uses it's value to determine the logging mode.)

member.name: M:SilDev.Log.AllowLogging
member.summary: Allows you to enable logging by command line arguments. For more information see .

member.summary: Provides options for specifying a Domain Name System provider.

member.name: F:SilDev.Network.NetEx.DnsOption.Cloudflare
member.summary: Partnership between Cloudflare and APNIC. Cloudflare runs one of the worlds largest, fastest networks. APNIC is a non-profit organization managing IP address allocation for the Asia Pacific and Oceania regions. Cloudflare had the network. APNIC had the IP address (1.1.1.1). Both were motivated by a mission to help build a better Internet.

member.name: F:SilDev.Network.NetEx.DnsOption.Google
member.summary: A free, global DNS resolution service that you can use as an alternative to your current DNS provider. In addition to traditional DNS over UDP or TCP, Google also provide DNS-over-HTTPS API.

The DNS servers to be used for the checks.

member.name: M:SilDev.Network.NetEx.Ping(System.Uri,System.Int32)
member.summary: Attempts to send an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo message to the specified computer, and receive a corresponding ICMP echo replay message from that computer and returns the number of milliseconds taken for this task.
member.param: The address of the server to call.
The maximum number of milliseconds (after sending the echo message) to wait for the ICMP echo reply message.

member.name: M:SilDev.PathEx.GetUniqueName(System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a unique name starting with a given prefix, followed by a hash of the specified length and a specified suffix.
member.param:
This text is at the beginning of the name.
Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the prefix.

This text is at the end of the name.
If it does not begin with a dot, it will be added. Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the suffix.
The length of the hash. Valid values are 4 through 24.
member.exception: prefix or suffix contains invalid characters.

member.name: M:SilDev.PathEx.GetUniquePath(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a fully qualified path with unique name starting with a given prefix, followed by a hash of the specified length and a specified suffix.
member.param: This home directory for the uniquely named file or directory.

This text is at the beginning of the name.
Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the prefix.

This text is at the end of the name.
If it does not begin with a dot, it will be added. Uppercase letters are converted to lowercase letters. Supported characters are only from '0' to '9' and from 'a' to 'z' but can be completely empty to omit the suffix.
The length of the hash. Valid values are 4 through 24.
member.exception: baseDir is not a valid path.
namePrefix or nameSuffix contains invalid characters.

member.name: T:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState
member.summary: Provides enumerated options that control the current state of the progress button.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState.NoProgress
member.summary: Stops displaying progress and returns the button to its normal state. Call this method with this flag to dismiss the progress bar when the operation is complete or canceled.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState.Indeterminate
member.summary: The progress indicator does not grow in size, but cycles repeatedly along the length of the taskbar button. This indicates activity without specifying what proportion of the progress is complete. Progress is taking place, but there is no prediction as to how long the operation will take.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState.Normal
member.summary: The progress indicator grows in size from left to right in proportion to the estimated amount of the operation completed. This is a determinate progress indicator; a prediction is being made as to the duration of the operation.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState.Error
member.summary: The progress indicator turns red to show that an error has occurred in one of the windows that is broadcasting progress. This is a determinate state. If the progress indicator is in the indeterminate state, it switches to a red determinate display of a generic percentage not indicative of actual progress.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarProgressState.Paused
member.summary: The progress indicator turns yellow to show that progress is currently stopped in one of the windows but can be resumed by the user. No error condition exists and nothing is preventing the progress from continuing. This is a determinate state. If the progress indicator is in the indeterminate state, it switches to a yellow determinate display of a generic percentage not indicative of actual progress.

member.name: T:SilDev.TaskBarState
member.summary: Provides enumerated options that control the current state of the taskbar.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarState.AutoHide
member.summary: The taskbar is in the autohide state.

member.name: F:SilDev.TaskBarState.AlwaysOnTop
member.summary:
The taskbar is in the always-on-top state.
Note that as of Windows 7, AlwaysOnTop is no longer returned because the taskbar is always in that state.

function.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.HorPositive
member.summary: Animates the window from left to right. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.HorNegative
member.summary: Animates the window from right to left. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.VerPositive
member.summary: Animates the window from top to bottom. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.VerNegative
member.summary: Animates the window from bottom to top. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.Center
member.summary: Makes the window appear to collapse inward if is used or expand outward if the is not used. The various direction flags have no effect.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.Hide
member.summary: Hides the window. By default, the window is shown.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.Activate
member.summary: Activates the window. Do not use this value with .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.Slide
member.summary: Uses slide animation. By default, roll animation is used. This flag is ignored when used with .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AnimateWindowFlags.Blend
member.summary: Uses a fade effect. This flag can be used only if hwnd is a top-level window.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AppBarMessageOption.GetTaskBarPos
member.summary: Retrieves the bounding rectangle of the Windows taskbar. Note that this applies only to the system taskbar. Other objects, particularly toolbars supplied with third-party software, also can be present. As a result, some of the screen area not covered by the Windows taskbar might not be visible to the user. To retrieve the area of the screen not covered by both the taskbar and other app bars-the working area available to your application-, use the GetMonitorInfo function.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.AppBarMessageOption.Activate

member.summary: Same as .
