member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetProcessWorkingSetSize(System.IntPtr,System.UIntPtr,System.UIntPtr)
member.summary: Sets the minimum and maximum working set sizes for the specified process.
member.param:
A handle to the process whose working set sizes is to be set.
The handle must have the access right.

The minimum working set size for the process, in bytes. The virtual memory manager attempts to keep at least this much memory resident in the process whenever the process is active.
This parameter must be greater than zero but less than or equal to the maximum working set size. The default size is 50 pages (for example, this is 204,800 bytes on systems with a 4K page size). If the value is greater than zero but less than 20 pages, the minimum value is set to 20 pages.
If both dwMinimumWorkingSetSize and dwMaximumWorkingSetSize have the value (SIZE_T)1, the function removes as many pages as possible from the working set of the specified process.

The maximum working set size for the process, in bytes. The virtual memory manager attempts to keep no more than this much memory resident in the process whenever the process is active and available memory is low.
This parameter must be greater than or equal to 13 pages (for example, 53,248 on systems with a 4K page size), and less than the system-wide maximum (number of available pages minus 512 pages). The default size is 345 pages (for example, this is 1,413,120 bytes on systems with a 4K page size).
If both dwMinimumWorkingSetSize and dwMaximumWorkingSetSize have the value (SIZE_T)1, the function removes as many pages as possible from the working set of the specified process.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetStdHandle(System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Sets the handle for the specified standard device (standard input, standard output, or standard error).
member.param: The standard device for which the handle is to be set.
The handle for the standard device.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetTimer(System.IntPtr,System.UIntPtr,System.UInt32,SilDev.WinApi.TimerProc)
member.summary: Creates a timer with the specified time-out value.
member.param: A handle to the window to be associated with the timer. This window must be owned by the calling thread. If a value for hWnd is passed in along with an nIDEvent of an existing timer, that timer will be replaced in the same way that an existing non- hWnd timer will be.

A nonzero timer identifier. If the hWnd parameter is , and the nIDEvent does not match an existing timer then it is ignored and a new timer ID is generated. If the hWnd parameter is not and the window specified by hWnd already has a timer with the value nIDEvent, then the existing timer is replaced by the new timer. When SetTimer replaces a timer, the timer is reset. Therefore, a message will be sent after the current time-out value elapses, but the previously set time-out value is ignored. If the call is not intended to replace an existing timer, nIDEvent should be 0 if the hWnd is .
The time-out value, in milliseconds.
A pointer to the function to be notified when the time-out value elapses.
member.returns:
If the function succeeds and the hWnd parameter is , the return value is an integer identifying the new timer. An application can pass this value to the KillTimer function to destroy the timer.
If the function succeeds and the hWnd parameter is not , then the return value is a nonzero integer. An application can pass the value of the nIDEvent parameter to the KillTimer function to destroy the timer.
If the function fails to create a timer, the return value is zero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowPlacement(System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.WindowPlacement@)
member.summary: Sets the show state and the restored, minimized, and maximized positions of the specified window.
member.param: A handle to the window.

A pointer to a structure that specifies the new show state and window positions.
Before calling SetWindowPlacement, set the length member of the structure to sizeof( ). SetWindowPlacement fails if the length member is not set correctly.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowPos(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,SilDev.WinApi.SetWindowPosFlags)
member.summary: Changes the size, position, and Z order of a child, pop-up, or top-level window. These windows are ordered according to their appearance on the screen. The topmost window receives the highest rank and is the first window in the Z order.
member.param: A handle to the window.

A handle to the window to precede the positioned window in the Z order. This parameter must be a window handle or one of the following values.
HWND_BOTTOM ((HWND)1): Places the window at the bottom of the Z order. If the hWnd parameter identifies a topmost window, the window loses its topmost status and is placed at the bottom of all other windows.
HWND_NOTOPMOST ((HWND)-2): Places the window above all non-topmost windows (that is, behind all topmost windows). This flag has no effect if the window is already a non-topmost window.
HWND_TOP ((HWND)0): Places the window at the top of the Z order.
HWND_TOPMOST ((HWND)-1): Places the window above all non-topmost windows. The window maintains its topmost position even when it is deactivated.
The new position of the left side of the window, in client coordinates.
The new position of the top of the window, in client coordinates.
The new width of the window, in pixels.
The new height of the window, in pixels.
The window sizing and positioning flags.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowsHookEx(SilDev.WinApi.Win32HookFlags,SilDev.WinApi.HookProc,System.IntPtr,System.Int32)
member.summary: Installs an application-defined hook procedure into a hook chain. You would install a hook procedure to monitor the system for certain types of events. These events are associated either with a specific thread or with all threads in the same desktop as the calling thread.
member.param: The type of hook procedure to be installed.

A pointer to the hook procedure. If the dwThreadId parameter is zero or specifies the identifier of a thread created by a different process, the lpfn parameter must point to a hook procedure in a DLL. Otherwise, lpfn can point to a hook procedure in the code associated with the current process.

A handle to the DLL containing the hook procedure pointed to by the lpfn parameter. The hMod parameter must be set to if the dwThreadId parameter specifies a thread created by the current process and if the hook procedure is within the code associated with the current process.

The identifier of the thread with which the hook procedure is to be associated. For desktop apps, if this parameter is zero, the hook procedure is associated with all existing threads running in the same desktop as the calling thread. For Windows Store apps, see the Remarks section.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the handle to the hook procedure. If the function fails, the return value is .

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowText(System.IntPtr,System.String)
member.summary: Changes the text of the specified window's title bar (if it has one). If the specified window is a control, the text of the control is changed. However, SetWindowText cannot change the text of a control in another application.
member.param: A handle to the window or control whose text is to be changed.
The new title or control text.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowTheme(System.IntPtr,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Causes a window to use a different set of visual style information than its class normally uses.
member.param: A handle to the window whose visual style information is to be changed.
Pointer to a string that contains the application name to use in place of the calling application's name. If this parameter is , the calling application's name is used.

Pointer to a string that contains a semicolon-separated list of CLSID names to use in place of the actual list passed by the window's class. If this parameter is , the ID list from the calling class is used.
member.returns: If this function succeeds, it returns S_OK. Otherwise, it returns an HRESULT error code.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SetWindowThemeAttribute(System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.WindowThemeAttributeTypes,SilDev.WinApi.WindowThemeAttributeOptions@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Sets attributes to control how visual styles are applied to a specified window.
member.param: Handle to a window to apply changes to.
Value of type that specifies the type of attribute to set.
A pointer that specifies attributes to set. Type is determined by the value of the eAttribute value.
Specifies the size, in bytes, of the data pointed to by pvAttribute.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SHAppBarMessage(SilDev.WinApi.AppBarMessageOption,SilDev.WinApi.AppBarData@)
member.summary: Sends an appbar message to the system.
member.param: Appbar message value to send.
A pointer to an structure. The content of the structure on entry and on exit depends on the value set in the dwMessage parameter. See the individual message pages for specifics.
member.returns: This function returns a message-dependent value. For more information, see the Windows SDK documentation for the specific appbar message sent. Links to those documents are given in the See Also section.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.ShellExecute(System.IntPtr,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,SilDev.WinApi.ShowWindowFlags)
member.summary: Performs an operation on a specified file.
member.param: A handle to the parent window used for displaying a UI or error messages. This value can be if the operation is not associated with a window.

A pointer to a null-terminated string, referred to in this case as a verb, that specifies the action to be performed. The set of available verbs depends on the particular file or folder. Generally, the actions available from an object's shortcut menu are available verbs.

A pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the file or object on which to execute the specified verb. To specify a Shell namespace object, pass the fully qualified parse name. Note that not all verbs are supported on all objects. For example, not all document types support the "print" verb. If a relative path is used for the lpDirectory parameter do not use a relative path for lpFile.

If lpFile specifies an executable file, this parameter is a pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the parameters to be passed to the application. The format of this string is determined by the verb that is to be invoked. If lpFile specifies a document file, lpParameters should be .

A pointer to a null-terminated string that specifies the default (working) directory for the action. If this value is , the current working directory is used. If a relative path is provided at lpFile, do not use a relative path for lpDirectory.

The flags that specify how an application is to be displayed when it is opened. If lpFile specifies a document file, the flag is simply passed to the associated application. It is up to the application to decide how to handle it.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, it returns a value greater than 32. If the function fails, it returns an error value that indicates the cause of the failure. The return value is cast as an HINSTANCE for backward compatibility with 16-bit Windows applications. It is not a HINSTANCE, however.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.SHGetFileInfo(System.String,System.UInt32,SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo@,System.UInt32,SilDev.WinApi.FileInfoFlags)
member.summary: Retrieves information about an object in the file system, such as a file, folder, directory, or drive root.
member.param:
A pointer to a null-terminated string of maximum length MAX_PATH that contains the path and file name. Both absolute and relative paths are valid.
If the uFlags parameter includes the flag, this parameter must be the address of an ITEMIDLIST (PIDL) structure that contains the list of item identifiers that uniquely identifies the file within the Shell's namespace. The PIDL must be a fully qualified PIDL. Relative PIDLs are not allowed.
If the uFlags parameter includes the flag, this parameter does not have to be a valid file name. The function will proceed as if the file exists with the specified name and with the file attributes passed in the dwFileAttributes parameter. This allows you to obtain information about a file type by passing just the extension for pszPath and passing in dwFileAttributes.
This string can use either short (the 8.3 form) or long file names.
A combination of one or more file attribute flags (FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ values as defined in Winnt.h). If uFlags does not include the flag, this parameter is ignored.
Pointer to a structure to receive the file information.
The size, in bytes, of the structure pointed to by the psfi parameter.
The flags that specify the file information to retrieve.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.ShowScrollBar(System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.ShowScrollBarOption,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The ShowScrollBar function shows or hides the specified scroll bar.
member.param: Handle to a scroll bar control or a window with a standard scroll bar, depending on the value of the wBar parameter.
Specifies the scroll bar(s) to be shown or hidden.
Specifies whether the scroll bar is shown or hidden. If this parameter is , the scroll bar is shown; otherwise, it is hidden.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.ShowWindow(System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.ShowWindowFlags)
member.summary: Sets the specified window's show state.
member.param: A handle to the window.

Controls how the window is to be shown. This parameter is ignored the first time an application calls ShowWindow, if the program that launched the application provides a STARTUPINFO structure. Otherwise, the first time ShowWindow is called, the value should be the value obtained by the WinMain function in its nCmdShow parameter.
member.returns:
If the window was previously visible, the return value is nonzero.
If the window was previously hidden, the return value is zero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.ShowWindowAsync(System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.ShowWindowFlags)
member.summary: Sets the show state of a window without waiting for the operation to complete.
member.param: A handle to the window.
Controls how the window is to be shown. For a list of possible values, see the description of the ShowWindow function.
member.returns: If the operation was successfully started, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.StartService(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Starts a service.
member.param: A handle to the service. This handle is returned by the OpenService or CreateService function, and it must have the access right.
The number of strings in the lpServiceArgVectors array. If lpServiceArgVectors is , this parameter can be zero.

The null-terminated strings to be passed to the ServiceMain function for the service as arguments. If there are no arguments, this parameter can be . Otherwise, the first argument (lpServiceArgVectors[0]) is the name of the service, followed by any additional arguments (lpServiceArgVectors[1] through lpServiceArgVectors[dwNumServiceArgs-1]).
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.TerminateProcess(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Terminates the specified process and all of its threads.
member.param:
A handle to the process to be terminated.
The handle must have the access right.

The exit code to be used by the process and threads terminated as a result of this call. Use the GetExitCodeProcess function to retrieve a process's exit value. Use the GetExitCodeThread function to retrieve a thread's exit value.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.TimeBeginPeriod(System.UInt32)
member.summary: The timeBeginPeriod function requests a minimum resolution for periodic timers.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application or device driver. A lower value specifies a higher (more accurate) resolution.
member.returns: Returns TIMERR_NOERROR if successful or TIMERR_NOCANDO if the resolution specified in uPeriod is out of range.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.TimeEndPeriod(System.UInt32)
member.summary: The timeEndPeriod function clears a previously set minimum timer resolution.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the timeBeginPeriod function.
member.returns: Returns TIMERR_NOERROR if successful or TIMERR_NOCANDO if the resolution specified in uPeriod is out of range.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.UnhookWindowsHookEx(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Removes a hook procedure installed in a hook chain by the SetWindowsHookEx function.
member.param: A handle to the hook to be removed. This parameter is a hook handle obtained by a previous call SetWindowsHookEx.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.UpdateWindow(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The UpdateWindow function updates the client area of the specified window by sending a WM_PAINT message to the window if the window's update region is not empty. The function sends a WM_PAINT message directly to the window procedure of the specified window, bypassing the application queue. If the update region is empty, no message is sent.
member.param: Handle to the window to be updated.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.VirtualAllocEx(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.MemAllocTypes,SilDev.WinApi.MemProtectFlags)
member.summary: Reserves, commits, or changes the state of a region of memory within the virtual address space of a specified process. The function initializes the memory it allocates to zero.
member.param:
The handle to a process. The function allocates memory within the virtual address space of this process.
The handle must have the access right.
The pointer that specifies a desired starting address for the region of pages that you want to allocate.
The size of the region of memory to allocate, in bytes.
The type of memory allocation. This parameter must contain one of the following values.
The memory protection for the region of pages to be allocated.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the base address of the allocated region of pages.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.VirtualFreeEx(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,SilDev.WinApi.MemFreeType)
member.summary: Releases, decommits, or releases and decommits a region of memory within the virtual address space of a specified process.
member.param:
The handle to a process. The function allocates memory within the virtual address space of this process.
The handle must have the access right.

A pointer to the starting address of the region of memory to be freed.
If the dwFreeType parameter is , lpAddress must be the base address returned by the VirtualAllocEx function when the region is reserved.

The size of the region of memory to free, in bytes.
If the dwFreeType parameter is , dwSize must be 0 (zero). The function frees the entire region that is reserved in the initial allocation call to VirtualAllocEx.
If dwFreeType is , the function decommits all memory pages that contain one or more bytes in the range from the lpAddress parameter to (lpAddress+dwSize). This means, for example, that a 2-byte region of memory that straddles a page boundary causes both pages to be decommitted. If lpAddress is the base address returned by VirtualAllocEx and dwSize is 0 (zero), the function decommits the entire region that is allocated by VirtualAllocEx. After that, the entire region is in the reserved state.
The type of free operation.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a nonzero value.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.WaveOutGetVolume(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: The waveOutGetVolume function retrieves the current volume level of the specified waveform-audio output device.
member.param: Handle to an open waveform-audio output device. This parameter can also be a device identifier.

Pointer to a variable to be filled with the current volume setting. The low-order word of this location contains the left-channel volume setting, and the high-order word contains the right-channel setting. A value of 0xFFFF represents full volume, and a value of 0x0 is silence.
member.returns: Returns MMSYSERR_NOERROR if successful or an error otherwise.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.WaveOutSetVolume(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The waveOutSetVolume function sets the volume level of the specified waveform-audio output device.
member.param: Handle to an open waveform-audio output device. This parameter can also be a device identifier.

New volume setting. The low-order word contains the left-channel volume setting, and the high-order word contains the right-channel setting. A value of 0xFFFF represents full volume, and a value of 0x0 is silence.
member.returns: Returns MMSYSERR_NOERROR if successful or an error otherwise.

member.summary: Copies a string into the specified section of an initialization file.
member.param: The name of the key to be associated with a string. If the key does not exist in the specified section, it is created. If this parameter is , the entire section, including all entries within the section, is deleted.
A null-terminated string to be written to the file. If this parameter is , the key pointed to by the lpKeyName parameter is deleted.
The name of the initialization file.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

member.name: M:SilDev.WinApi.NativeMethods.WriteProcessMemory(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: Writes data to an area of memory in a specified process. The entire area to be written to must be accessible or the operation fails.
member.param: A handle to the process memory to be modified. The handle must have and access to the process.

A pointer to the base address in the specified process to which data is written. Before data transfer occurs, the system verifies that all data in the base address and memory of the specified size is accessible for write access, and if it is not accessible, the function fails.
A pointer to the buffer that contains data to be written in the address space of the specified process.
The number of bytes to be written to the specified process.
A pointer to a variable that receives the number of bytes transferred into the specified process. This parameter is optional. If lpNumberOfBytesWritten is , the parameter is ignored.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.

The zero-based offset to the value to be set. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of an integer.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.ProcessInformation
member.summary: Contains information about a newly created process and its primary thread.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ProcessInformation.hProcess
member.summary: A handle to the newly created process. The handle is used to specify the process in all functions that perform operations on the process object.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ProcessInformation.hThread
member.summary: A handle to the primary thread of the newly created process. The handle is used to specify the thread in all functions that perform operations on the thread object.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ProcessInformation.dwProcessId
member.summary: A value that can be used to identify a process. The value is valid from the time the process is created until all handles to the process are closed and the process object is freed; at this point, the identifier may be reused.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ProcessInformation.dwThreadId
member.summary: A value that can be used to identify a thread. The value is valid from the time the thread is created until all handles to the thread are closed and the thread object is freed; at this point, the identifier may be reused.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.SecurityAttributes
member.summary: Contains the security descriptor for an object and specifies whether the handle retrieved by specifying this structure is inheritable. This structure provides security settings for objects created by various functions.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.SecurityAttributes.nLength
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of this structure. Set this value to the size of the structure.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.SecurityAttributes.lpSecurityDescriptor
member.summary: A pointer to a security descriptor structure that controls access to the object. If the value of this member is , the object is assigned the default security descriptor associated with the access token of the calling process. This is not the same as granting access to everyone by assigning a discretionary access control list (DACL). By default, the default DACL in the access token of a process allows access only to the user represented by the access token.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.SecurityAttributes.bInheritHandle
member.summary: A value that specifies whether the returned handle is inherited when a new process is created. If this member is , the new process inherits the handle.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus
member.summary: Contains status information for a service.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwCheckPoint
member.summary: The check-point value the service increments periodically to report its progress during a lengthy start, stop, pause, or continue operation. For example, the service should increment this value as it completes each step of its initialization when it is starting up. The user interface program that invoked the operation on the service uses this value to track the progress of the service during a lengthy operation. This value is not valid and should be zero when the service does not have a start, stop, pause, or continue operation pending.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwControlsAccepted
member.summary: The control codes the service accepts and processes in its handler function (see Handler and HandlerEx). A user interface process can control a service by specifying a control command in the ControlService or ControlServiceEx function. By default, all services accept the value. To accept the SERVICE_CONTROL_DEVICEEVENT value, the service must register to receive device events by using the RegisterDeviceNotification function.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwCurrentState
member.summary: The current state of the service.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwServiceSpecificExitCode
member.summary: A service-specific error code that the service returns when an error occurs while the service is starting or stopping. This value is ignored unless the dwWin32ExitCode member is set to ERROR_SERVICE_SPECIFIC_ERROR.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwServiceType
member.summary: The type of service.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwWaitHint
member.summary: The estimated time required for a pending start, stop, pause, or continue operation, in milliseconds. Before the specified amount of time has elapsed, the service should make its next call to the SetServiceStatus function with either an incremented dwCheckPoint value or a change in dwCurrentState. If the amount of time specified by dwWaitHint passes, and dwCheckPoint has not been incremented or dwCurrentState has not changed, the service control manager or service control program can assume that an error has occurred and the service should be stopped. However, if the service shares a process with other services, the service control manager cannot terminate the service application because it would have to terminate the other services sharing the process as well.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ServiceStatus.dwWin32ExitCode
member.summary: The error code the service uses to report an error that occurs when it is starting or stopping. To return an error code specific to the service, the service must set this value to ERROR_SERVICE_SPECIFIC_ERROR to indicate that the dwServiceSpecificExitCode member contains the error code. The service should set this value to NO_ERROR when it is running and on normal termination.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo
member.summary: Specifies the window station, desktop, standard handles, and appearance of the main window for a process at creation time.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.cb
member.summary: The size of the structure, in bytes.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.lpReserved
member.summary: Reserved; must be .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.lpDesktop
member.summary: The name of the desktop, or the name of both the desktop and window station for this process. A backslash in the string indicates that the string includes both the desktop and window station names.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.lpTitle
member.summary: For console processes, this is the title displayed in the title bar if a new console window is created. If , the name of the executable file is used as the window title instead. This parameter must be for GUI or console processes that do not create a new console window.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwX
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the x offset of the upper left corner of a window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwY

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwXSize
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the width of the window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwYSize
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the height of the window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwXCountChars
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , if a new console window is created in a console process, this member specifies the screen buffer width, in character columns. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwYCountChars
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , if a new console window is created in a console process, this member specifies the screen buffer height, in character rows. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwFillAttribute
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the initial text and background colors if a new console window is created in a console application. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.dwFlags
member.summary: A bitfield that determines whether certain members are used when the process creates a window.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.wShowWindow
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies .

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.cbReserved2
member.summary: Reserved for use by the C Run-time; must be zero.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.lpReserved2
member.summary: Reserved for use by the C Run-time; must be zero.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.hStdInput
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the standard input handle for the process. If is not specified, the default for standard input is the keyboard buffer.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.hStdOutput
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the standard output handle for the process. Otherwise, this member is ignored and the default for standard output is the console window's buffer.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.StartupInfo.hStdError
member.summary: If dwFlags specifies , this member is the standard error handle for the process. Otherwise, this member is ignored and the default for standard error is the console window's buffer.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.DwmColorizationParams
member.summary: Contains information about the colorization of Windows.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.Process

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.strAppName
member.summary: If the process is a service, this parameter returns the long name for the service. If the process is not a service, this parameter returns the user-friendly name for the application. If the process is a critical process, and the installer is run with elevated privileges, this parameter returns the name of the executable file of the critical process. If the process is a critical process, and the installer is run as a service, this parameter returns the long name of the critical process.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.strServiceShortName
member.summary: If the process is a service, this is the short name for the service. This member is not used if the process is not a service.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.ApplicationType

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.AppStatus
member.summary: Contains a bit mask that describes the current status of the application. See the RM_APP_STATUS enumeration.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.TSSessionId
member.summary: Contains the Terminal Services session ID of the process. If the terminal session of the process cannot be determined, the value of this member is set to RM_INVALID_SESSION (-1). This member is not used if the process is a service or a system critical process.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmProcessInfo.bRestartable
member.summary: if the application can be restarted by the Restart Manager; otherwise, . This member is always if the process is a service. This member is always if the process is a critical system process.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.RmUniqueProcess
member.summary: Uniquely identifies a process by its PID and the time the process began. An array of RM_UNIQUE_PROCESS structures can be passed to the RmRegisterResources function.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmUniqueProcess.dwProcessId
member.summary: The product identifier (PID).

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.RmUniqueProcess.ProcessStartTime
member.summary: The creation time of the process. The time is provided as a FILETIME structure that is returned by the lpCreationTime parameter of the GetProcessTimes function.

member.name: T:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo
member.summary: Contains information about a file object.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo.hIcon
member.summary: A handle to the icon that represents the file. You are responsible for destroying this handle with DestroyIcon when you no longer need it.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo.iIcon
member.summary: The index of the icon image within the system image list.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo.dwAttributes
member.summary: An array of values that indicates the attributes of the file object. For information about these values, see the IShellFolder::GetAttributesOf method.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo.szDisplayName
member.summary: A string that contains the name of the file as it appears in the Windows Shell, or the path and file name of the file that contains the icon representing the file.

member.name: F:SilDev.WinApi.ShFileInfo.szTypeName
member.summary: A string that describes the type of file.
